items.title: A peek inside my pocket notebook
items.description: <![CDATA[My pocket notebook is my least-formal of my 4 notebooks, so it usually turns out to be my favorite and most surprising notebook to flip through. Here’s a peek inside my latest.]]>

items.title: Typewriter interview with Sarah Manguso
items.description: <![CDATA[After a brief hiatus, the typewriter interviews are back! The latest is a great one with writer Sarah Manguso.]]>

items.title: Writing shouldn’t be easier
items.description: <![CDATA[Here’s a page from my diary that I put at the top of today’s newsletter: “Making it easier.”]]>

items.title: Gift ideas for dads & grads
items.description: <![CDATA[It’s what folks in the book industry call “Dads & Grads” season. Here are two ideas: 1. Give them one of my books with a few crisp bills as a bookmark. (When in doubt about which book of mine to give, I suggest the deluxe hardcover anniversary edition of Steal Like an Artist.) 2. Gift […]]]>

items.title: May 2025 mixtape
items.description: <![CDATA[Here is a mopey, gloomy, gothy, synthy mixtape for a heating earth. A cousin to Dancing in the Ruins. I made it from a sealed, pre-recorded cassette I got for 99 cents at the record store. I taped over the cassette’s protection tabs and then I taped over the music and then I taped over […]]]>

items.title: Kubrick, Peep Show, and internal monologues
items.description: <![CDATA[Today’s newsletter was an excuse to write about the weird experience of binge-watching Peep Show after watching and reading about 2001: A Space Odyssey: “Do you hear an internal monologue?”]]>

items.title: April Showers (a mixtape)
items.description: <![CDATA[After I started May’s mixtape, I remembered that I never posted April’s mix. I made it from a sealed, pre-recorded cassette I got for 99 cents at the record store. I taped over the cassette’s protection tabs and then I taped over the music and then I taped over the artwork. This is another “sad […]]]>

items.title: Maycember rage
items.description: <![CDATA[From a Parents.com article titled “Maycember’ Madness Is Real and Leaving Parents Even More Burned Out”: Much like the month of December, my packed calendar at the end of the school year has left me feeling like there’s not so much joy, as obligation and overwhelm. Instead of cruising into summer with a sense of […]]]>

items.title: 3 thoughts while pushing a wheelbarrow
items.description: <![CDATA[In Tuesday’s letter, I tried to weave together some ideas about yard work, Larry McMurtry, and giving yourself time to feel things, and I managed to articulate something I hadn’t articulated before: The computer used to mean the world to me. The computer was a portal to the world I wished to be in. Times […]]]>

items.title: We’ll see
items.description: <![CDATA[Today’s letter is titled “We’ll see!” “We’ll see” is the refrain in the Charlie Wilson’s War version of the 2000-year-old Chinese parable about the old man who lost his horse. (Bluey used the same refrain, while Alan Watts used “Maybe.”) It’s a favorite parable of mine and one I think about often. Here’s how Ursula K. […]]]>
